title: Introducing Logical-First Architecture, the Real ‚ÄúZero-Copy‚Äù Architecture
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-16, Reading time: 4 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fwww.datamanagementblog.com%2Fintroducing-logical-first-architecture-the-real-zero-copy-architecture%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdata/1/0100019c66230c28-21b592cd-cb6d-4261-b1d5-896629d9960a-000000/IjeXc4BTeQHG4hxfXh5finkyaRIwmitvdrEDlD4P5jQ=444
summary: Introducing Logical-First Architecture, the Real ‚ÄúZero-Copy‚Äù Architecture (4 minute read) A Logical-First Architecture is a true zero-copy approach that prioritizes logical access over physical data movement, leaving data in its original sources while enabling unified views, federation, and querying without duplication. Unlike traditional ETL/ELT pipelines or lakehouses that replicate data, it avoids storage bloat, latency, governance complexity, and unnecessary cost.

title: Bias Toward Action
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-16, Reading time: 17 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Faddyosmani.com%2Fblog%2Fbias-towards-action%2F%3Futm_source=tldrnewsletter/1/0100019c66335a94-028c14eb-82c0-4dab-82c4-270158ceb4fd-000000/tsSngAp3SD5GPOHN6iwUzLDwcWmE53WifDyM15k3hqY=444
summary: Bias Toward Action (17 minute read) Bias toward action is defaulting to the smallest responsible step that produces real feedback while pre-committing to guardrails. It helps companies learn faster while making sure that being wrong doesn't kill them. It's about optimizing for learning speed while investing in foundations that make you faster. Fast teams use a lot of information, but they don't wait for perfect information. Their tight feedback loops allow them to learn quickly.

title: How NOT to Answer the Salary Question
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-17, Reading time: 12 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fadatosystems.com%2F2026%2F02%2F16%2Fblog-how-not-to-answer-the-salary-question%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019c6b814d36-dd5167a9-bd76-457d-ba45-3c9471989cd9-000000/tbkkVsnqr6m02gTsTyjGRIAJNyq0w_t_kw7J0btCKLI=444
summary: How NOT to Answer the Salary Question (12 minute read) Job seekers should avoid answering the salary question too early in the interview process. Discussing salary before understanding the full job responsibilities and benefits is unhelpful for both parties and can lead to being undervalued. Candidates should deflect the question by focusing on industry-standard ranges, the comprehensive benefits package, or the detailed nature of the role itself.

summary: WebMCP (Website) The WebMCP API is a new JavaScript interface that enables web apps to expose their functionality as "tools" for AI agents. This allows various agents, including LLM-based AI platforms, browser agents, and assistive technologies, to invoke client-side web application logic.

title: The only developer productivity metrics that matter

summary: The only developer productivity metrics that matter (2 minute read) Most software productivity metrics are meaningless because teams can game them. comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-18, Reading time: 6 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Femschwartz.me%2Fpsa-write-transactions-are-a-footgun-with-sqlx-and-sqlite%2F%3Futm_source=tldrdev/1/0100019c70a8d69c-ae2ef20b-64fc-450e-94ce-5e46527b7527-000000/xFmcEwGdv7LwsqdW4fKxQm5gyjDZ5ysbCBRO09ehG8w=445

title: Building on Sand: The Hidden Cost of AI Model Churn

summary: Building on Sand: The Hidden Cost of AI Model Churn (13 minute read) AI pushes technical complexity upstream into the problem space, where the PM lives. This means the PM must become the architect because architecture is now a product artifact. An AI model update can invalidate assumptions, making it impossible to define products, user experience, feasibility, or cost. The only way to build durable AI products is to design systems that assume the model will change.

title: How to Sell to Agents
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-18, Reading time: 7 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2FC3zvsP/1/0100019c70de1858-3903622e-2f2d-4809-bbbc-afd6adff9363-000000/qak0k9Grh6QgrglJMzBUofrznZJGOIdzcwOO6kqs2J4=444
summary: How to Sell to Agents (7 minute read) In 1937, Ronald Coase asked why firms existed if markets are so efficient. His answer was transaction costs. AI agents are about to collapse those costs to near zero. An agent can discover a service, check its price, and call it in a single HTTP round-trip. HTTP 402 - "Payment Required" - has been reserved for future use since 1997. We're finally finding that use. The web was built for humans to browse. The next layer will be built for agents to buy.

title: Navigating a Paradigm Shift
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-18, Reading time: 3 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Flinks.tldrnewsletter.com%2F0bQwjA/1/0100019c70de1858-3903622e-2f2d-4809-bbbc-afd6adff9363-000000/TzaGfdZHj8yyafR3Du4uorKUrLaIw--PY8wAPKTgMWQ=444
summary: Navigating a Paradigm Shift (3 minute read) The hardest part of a paradigm shift is navigating it while it's incomplete. Paradigm shifts are tectonic shifts beneath markets, technologies, and human thought. They begin quietly at first, then the world suddenly bends. Paradigm shifts begin with dissonance, not consensus, as the old ways no longer fit the new reality. The best founders understand why the current system works, but believe there are better ways to do things.

title: A Primer on Factory Economics for Startups
comment: Source: TLDR Newsletter, Date: 2026-02-18, Reading time: 20 minute read, Links: https://tracking.tldrnewsletter.com/CL0/https:%2F%2Fa16z.com%2Fa-primer-on-factory-economics-for-startups%2F%3Futm_source=tldrfounders/1/0100019c70de1858-3903622e-2f2d-4809-bbbc-afd6adff9363-000000/oSddIxN68NokZ99HbSbtiuoa7L9LzOcYFqPY1fE4Icc=444
summary: A Primer on Factory Economics for Startups (20 minute read) Tesla popularized the "factory-is-the-product" thesis. It now applies to companies making drone motors, robot actuators, PCBs, and battery packs. The learning curve is central to strategy: for each doubling of cumulative production, costs fall predictably. Your competitive position depends on where you are on the curve, how fast you descend, and whether you can finance the journey.
